# L4.6
Multistage Amplifiers

__Dr\. Yasen Harrye__

<span style="color:#961a26"> __Multistage Amplifiers:__ </span>

Many applications cannot be handled with single\-transistor amplifiers in order to meet the specification of a   given  <span style="color:#ff0000">amplification gain</span> \,  <span style="color:#ff0000">input resistance </span> and  <span style="color:#ff0000">output resistance</span> \.

As a solution – a transistor amplifier circuits can be connected in series or as a cascaded amplifiers\.

This can be done either to increase the overall small\-signal voltage gain or provide an overall voltage gain greater than l with a very low output resistance\.

<span style="color:#961a26"> __Multistage Amplifiers:__ </span>

<span style="color:#ff0000"> __Darlington Connection__ </span>

![](l4.6-multistage-amplifier-img/l46-multistage-amplifier_1.png)

A very popular connection of two bipolar junction transistors for operation is "superbeta" transistor\.

The  <span style="color:#3c1dc1">main feature of the Darlington connection is that the current gain is the product of the current gains of the individual transistors</span> \.

![](l4.6-multistage-amplifier-img/l46-multistage-amplifier_2.png)

<span style="color:#961a26"> __Multistage Amplifiers:__ </span>

<span style="color:#ff0000"> __III Darlington Amplifier: Emitter Follower Configuration __ </span>

![](l4.6-multistage-amplifier-img/l46-multistage-amplifier_3.png)

Impact of using the Darlington configuration is an  <span style="color:#ff0000">input impedance </span> much larger than that obtained with a single\-transistor network\.

The  <span style="color:#ff0000">current gain </span> is also larger\.

But the  <span style="color:#ff0000"> _voltage gain _ </span> for a single\-transistor or Darlington configuration remains slightly less than one\.
